title: Faunus ater
text:
Faunus ater is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="brackish%20water">brackish water</a> snail with an <a href="Operculum%20%28gastropod%29">operculum</a>, an <a href="aquatic%20animal">aquatic</a> <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the family <a href="Pachychilidae">Pachychilidae</a>.
"Faunus ater" is the only species within the genus Faunus.
Distribution.
The distribution of "Faunus ater" includes:
Description.
The <a href="periostracum">periostracum</a> is thick, and the color of the periostracum is dark brown or black. The shell has about 20 <a href="whorl%20%28mollusc%29">whorls</a>. The apical whorls may be eroded in older snails. The <a href="aperture%20%28mollusc%29">aperture</a> is ovate and white. The <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> is unique among <a href="Cerithioidea">Cerithioidea</a>, because it has two deep sinuses: an anal sinus which is close to the <a href="suture%20%28gastropod%29">suture</a> and an anterior sinus more forward in the aperture. The height of the aperture is about one-fifth of the height of the shell.
The height of the shell is usually 50–60 mm, but can be up to 90 mm.
The <a href="Operculum%20%28gastropod%29">operculum</a> is oval, <a href="corneous">corneous</a> and dark brown in color.
The snail has a broad <a href="snout">snout</a>. The <a href="radula">radula</a> is large and is located in a correspondingly large <a href="buccal%20mass">buccal mass</a>.
Ecology.
This snail lives in slightly <a href="brackish%20water">brackish water</a>. It has also been reported from freshwater. It is the only pachychilid species that lives in brackish water; the other species in the family are <a href="freshwater%20snail">freshwater snail</a>s.
The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> can reach up to 6700 snails per m2.
This snail probably feeds by <a href="grazing">grazing</a>.
It is <a href="oviparous">oviparous</a>. It probably has free-swimming larvae.
Human use.
This snail is used as a <a href="Philippine%20cuisine">food source for humans in the Philippines</a> and in <a href="Thai%20cuisine">Thailand</a>.
